revision.comment: Remove 1 stray access-date. ([[User:GreenC bot/Job 5|GreenC bot job #5]])
revision.text:
[[File:Flaubert-Giraud.jpg|thumb|Flaubert at about the age of 50. Portrait by [[Eugène Giraud]]]] The '''letters of Gustave Flaubert''', the 19th-century French novelist, range in date from 1829, when he was 7 or 8 years old, to a day or two before his death in 1880.{{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/jet/public/correspondance/feuilletage_liste_elts.php?t=C |title=Présentation des lettres par ordre chronologique |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 November 2017 |website=Correspondence: Édition électronique |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |language=French |access-date=2 August 2018 }} They are considered one of the finest bodies of letters in French literature, admired even by many who are critical of [[Gustave Flaubert|Flaubert]]'s novels.{{sfn|Barnes|2003}} His main correspondents include family members, business associates and fellow-writers such as [[Théophile Gautier]], the [[Goncourt brothers]], [[Guy de Maupassant]], [[Charles Augustin Sainte-Beuve]], [[George Sand]], [[Ivan Turgenev]] and [[Émile Zola]]. They provide a valuable glimpse of his methods of work and his literary philosophy, as well as documenting his social life, political opinions, and increasing disgust with bourgeois society. == Correspondents == 4481 letters by Flaubert survive,{{sfn|Leclerc|Girard|2017}} a number which would have been considerably higher but for a series of burnings of his letters to his friends. Many of those addressed to [[Maxime Du Camp]], [[Guy de Maupassant]] and [[Louis Bouilhet]] were destroyed in this way.{{cite book |last1=Porter |first1=Laurence M. |last2=Gray |first2=Eugene F. |year=2002 |title=Gustave Flaubert's ''Madame Bovary'': A Reference Guide |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=T_BcAAAAMAAJ&q=%22most+of+his+letters+to+and+from+his+close+friends%22&dq=%22most+of+his+letters+to+and+from+his+close+friends%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiot9SCn87cAhXLyaQKHUWuCR8Q6AEIJzAA |location=Westport, Conn. |publisher=Greenwood Press |page=145 |isbn=0313319162 |access-date=2 August 2018 }} From those that survive it appears that his principal correspondents were as follows.{{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/jet/public/correspondance/feuilletage_liste_elts.php?corpus=correspondance |title=Présentation des lettres par destinataire |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 November 2017 |website=Correspondence: Édition électronique |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |language=French |access-date=2 August 2018 }} His family members:
{{columns-list|colwidth=25em| * Anne Justine Caroline Flaubert, his mother * Caroline Hamard, his sister * Caroline Commanvile, his niece * Ernest Commanville, his niece's husband }} His friends, associates and readers:
{{columns-list|colwidth=25em| * [[Agénor Bardoux]], politician * Princesse [[Mathilde Bonaparte]], niece of [[Napoleon|Napoleon I]], cousin of [[Napoleon III]], literary patron * [[Amélie Bosquet]] ([[:fr:Amélie Bosquet|FR]]), feminist writer * Louis Bouilhet, poet and friend of Flaubert from childhood * Marie-Louise Léonie Brainne (née Rivière), journalist * Maxime Du Camp, journalist, photographer and travelling companion of Flaubert * [[Marie-Sophie Leroyer de Chantepie]] ([[:fr:Marie-Sophie Leroyer de Chantepie|FR]]), minor novelist * [[Georges Charpentier]], publisher * [[Ernest Chevalier]] ([[:fr:Ernest Chevalier|FR]]), judge and friend from childhood * [[Louise Colet]], poet and Flaubert's lover * Jules Duplan, businessman * [[Ernest-Aimé Feydeau]], writer * Frédéric Fovard, notary * [[Théophile Gautier]], poet and writer * Edma Roger des Genettes, literary and artistic ''salonnière'' * [[Edmond de Goncourt|Edmond]] and [[Jules de Goncourt]], novelists and diarists * Edmond Laporte, local politician and businessman * [[Alphonse Lemerre]], publisher * Philippe Leparfait, adopted son of Louis Bouilhet * [[Michel Lévy]], publisher * Guy de Maupassant, short-story writer * [[Claudius Popelin]] ([[:fr:Claudius Popelin|FR]]), painter, writer and sometime lover of Princesse Mathilde Bonaparte * [[Edgar Raoul-Duval]], politician * [[Charles Augustin Sainte-Beuve]], critic and novelist * [[George Sand]], novelist * [[Hippolyte Taine]], writer on art and literature * [[Gertrude Tennant]], English society hostess * [[Marie-Anne Detourbay|Jeanne de Tourbey]], successful ''[[Demimonde|demi-mondaine]]'' * Jules Troubat, Sainte-Beuve's secretary * [[Ivan Turgenev]], Russian novelist * [[Émile Zola]], novelist{{sfn|Steegmuller|1954|pp=56–57}}{{cite news |last=Flood |first=Alison |date=27 July 2009 |title=Letters Reveal Flaubert's English 'Amitié Amoureuse' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/jul/27/flaubert-amitie-amoureuse-letters |work=The Guardian |location=London |access-date=2 August 2018 }}{{cite book |year=1980 |editor1-last=Steegmuller |editor1-first=Francis |title=The Letters of Gustave Flaubert 1830–1857 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=srZfwgWpQysC&pg=PA222&dq=%22contract+with+the+publisher+Michel%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiemcfFqs7cAhVrCsAKHQTdAJAQ6AEIOTAD#v=onepage&q=%22contract%20with%20the%20publisher%20Michel%22&f=false |location=Cambridge, Mass. |publisher=Belknap Press of the Harvard University Press |page=222 |isbn=0674526368 |access-date=2 August 2018 }}{{sfn|Steegmuller|1982|pp=5, 18, 65 108, 133, 195, 219, 250, 251}}{{sfn|Winock|2016|pp=230, 312}}{{cite book |year=1969 |editor1-last=Thorlby |editor1-first=Anthony |title=The Penguin Companion to Literature. 2: European |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=sIWnIOCXU7AC&q=%22French+critic+and+novelist+early%22&dq=%22French+critic+and+novelist+early%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjNtNDirc7cAhXKa8AKHa6NBxMQ6AEIKzAB |location=Harmondsworth |publisher=Penguin |pages=304, 686 |isbn=9780140510355 |access-date=2 August 2018 }} }} == Themes == Flaubert's personality was rigorously excluded from his novels, but in the letters, written at night after the day's literary work was done, he expresses much more spontaneously his own personal views.{{sfn|Steegmuller|1954|p=11}} Their themes often arise from his life as a reader and writer. They discuss the subject-matter and structural difficulties of his novels, and explore the problems Flaubert faced in their composition, giving the reader a unique glimpse of his art in the making.{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|p=76}} They illustrate his extensive reading of the creative literatures of France, England (he loved [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]], [[Lord Byron|Byron]] and [[Charles Dickens|Dickens]]), Germany and the classical world; also his deep researches into history, philosophy and the sciences.{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=74}}{{sfn|Barnes|2002|p=244}} Above all, they constantly state and restate Flaubert's belief in the duty of the writer to maintain his independence, and in his own need to reach literary beauty through a quasi-scientific objectivity.{{sfn|Steegmuller|1954|pp=17–18}}{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=75}}{{cite news |last=Hampshire |first=Stuart |author-link=Stuart Hampshire |date=16 December 1982 |title=In Flaubert's Laboratory |url=https://www.nybooks.com/articles/1982/12/16/in-flauberts-laboratory/ |work=The New York Review of Books |access-date=2 August 2018 }} But his letters also demonstrate an enjoyment of the simple pleasures of Flaubert's youth. Friendship, love, conversation, a delight in foreign travel, the pleasures of the table and of the bed are all in evidence.{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|p=67}}{{cite book |last1=Vidal |first1=Gore |author-link1=Gore Vidal |year=1982 |title=Pink Triangle and Yellow Star, and Other Essays (1976–1982) |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xDQgAQAAIAAJ&q=%22brothels+and+baths+of%22&dq=%22brothels+and+baths+of%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjul5S1l8_cAhXIK8AKHR8tD68Q6AEIQzAF |location=London |publisher=Heinemann |page=29 |isbn=9780434830756 |access-date=2 August 2018 }} These do not disappear in his maturer years, but they are offset by discussions of politics and current affairs which reveal an increasing disgust with society, especially bourgeois society, and with the age he lived in.{{cite book |last1=Lloyd |first1=Rosemary |year=2014 |orig-year=1990 |title=Madame Bovary |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0F4tBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA21&dq=%22flaubert's+letters%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3jIb9hK3aAhVlKsAKHdNpAMY4FBDoAQg-MAU#v=onepage&q=%22flaubert's%20letters%22&f=false |location=Abingdon |publisher=Routledge |page=21 |isbn=9781138799349 |access-date=2 August 2018 }}{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=74}} They exude a sadness and a sense of having grown old before his time.{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|p=80}} As a whole, said the literary critic Eric Le Calvez, Flaubert's correspondence, "reveals his vision of life and of the relation between life and art: since the human condition is miserable, life can be legitimated only through an eternal pursuit of art."{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=74}} == Critical reception == [[File:Flaubert letter.jpg|thumb|An 1877 letter from [[Gustave Flaubert]] to [[Léon Cladel]]]] For many years after the first publication of the letters critical opinion was divided. [[Albert Thibaudet]] thought them "the expression of a first-rate intellect", and [[André Gide]] wrote that "For more than five years his correspondence took the place of the Bible at my bedside. It was my reservoir of energy". [[Frank Harris]] said that in his letters "he lets himself go and unconsciously paints himself for us to the life; and this Gustave Flaubert is enormously more interesting than anything in ''Madame Bovary''".{{cite book |last1=Harris |first1=Frank |author-link1=Frank Harris |year=1927 |title=Latest Contemporary Portraits |location=New York |publisher=Macaulay |page=206 }} On the other hand [[Marcel Proust]] found Flaubert's epistolary style "even worse" than that of his novels, while for [[Henry James]] the Flaubert of the letters was "impossible as a companion".{{sfn|Steegmuller|1982|pp=xvii–xviii}} This ambivalence is a thing of the past, and there is now widespread agreement that the Flaubert correspondence is one of the finest in French literature.{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=74}} Publication of them "has crowned his reputation as the exemplary artist".{{cite web |url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780192806871.001.0001/acref-9780192806871-e-2807?rskey=3k4M21&result=4 |title=The Oxford Companion to English Literature (7 ed.) |date=2009 |editor-last=Birch |editor-first=Dinah |editor-link=Dinah Birch |website=Oxford Reference |publisher=Oxford University Press |access-date=2 August 2018 }} [[Enid Starkie]] wrote that Flaubert was one of his own greatest literary creations, and that the letters might well be seen in the future as his greatest book, and the one in which "he has most fully distilled his personality and his wisdom".{{cite book |last1=Starkie |first1=Enid |year=1971 |title=Flaubert the Master: A Critical and Biographical Study (1856-1880) |location=London |publisher=Weidenfeld and Nicolson |pages=355-356 |isbn=0297002260 }} [[Jean-Paul Sartre]], an inveterate enemy of Flaubert's novels, considered the letters a perfect example of pre-Freudian [[Free association (psychology)|free association]], and for [[Julian Barnes]] this description "hints at their fluency, profligacy, range and sexual frankness; to which we should add power, control, wit, emotion and furious intelligence. The ''Correspondance''...has always added up to Flaubert's best biography."{{sfn|Barnes|2002|p=239}}{{sfn|Barnes|2003}} Rosemary Lloyd analyses the elements of their appeal as being "partly [their] wide sweep, partly the sense of seeing what Baudelaire called the strings and pulleys of the writer's workshop, and partly the immediacy of Flaubert's changeable, complex and challenging personality." She continues, "Reading Flaubert's correspondence brings startlingly alive a man of enormous complexity, of remarkable appetites and debilitating lethargies, a knotted network of prejudices, insights, blind spots, passions and ambitions."{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|pp=67, 83}} == Editions == * {{cite book |last1=Flaubert |first1=Gustave |year=1887–1893 |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=G. Charpentier }} This four-volume edition was the first to try to collect Flaubert's letters. The unnamed editor was Flaubert's niece Caroline Commanville; she censored the letters freely, cutting out many passages which she thought indecent or which referred unflatteringly to living persons, especially to herself, and very often failing to notify the reader of these cuts by the use of [[Ellipsis|ellipses]]. She also corrected his punctuation and sometimes "improved" his phrasing.{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|p=68}}{{sfn|Steegmuller|1982|pp=xv–xvi}}{{sfn|Barnes|2003}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |last1=Flaubert |first1=Gustave |year=1910 |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=Conard }} A five-volume edition which has been described as "seriously flawed".{{sfn|Winock|2016|p=422}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1922–1925 |editor1-last=Descharmes |editor1-first=René |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=Librairie de France }} In four volumes. The first scholarly edition.{{sfn|Winock|2016|p=422}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |last1=Flaubert |first1=Gustave |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=Louis Conard }} In nine volumes, containing 1992 letters. Most of the notes were taken from René Descharmes' edition.{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=75}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1954 |editor1-last=Dumesnil |editor1-first=René |editor1-link=René Dumesnil |editor2-last=Pommier |editor2-first=Jean |editor3-last=Digeon |editor3-first=Claude |title=Correspondance: Supplément |location=Paris |publisher=Louis Conard, Jacques Lambert }} Adds 1296 letters to the edition of 1926–1933.{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=75}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1973–2007 |editor1-last=Bruneau |editor1-first=Jean |title=Correspondance |series=Bibliothèque de la Pléiade |location=Paris |publisher=Gallimard }} In five volumes, the first four edited by Jean Bruneau, and the fifth, which was published after Bruneau's death, co-edited with [[Yvan Leclerc]] ([[:fr:Yvan Leclerc|FR]]). This edition boasts an extremely thorough critical apparatus, with letters written to Flaubert, excerpts from the [[Goncourt Journal]] and other third-party documentation, together with explanatory and critical notes by the editor. Julian Barnes points out that in the third volume the appendices, notes and variants take up more pages than the letters themselves.{{cite news |last=Barnes |first=Julian |date=14 March 2008 |title=The Lost Governess |url=https://www.the-tls.co.uk/articles/public/julian-barnes-gustave-flaubert/ |work=TLS |location=London |access-date=3 August 2018 }}{{sfn|Barnes|2003}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1974–1976 |editor1-last=Bardèche |editor1-first=Maurice |editor1-link=Maurice Bardèche |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=Club de l'Honnête Homme }} In five volumes.{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=2001 |editor1-last=Bonaccorso |editor1-first=Giovanni |title=Correspondance. Première édition scientifique |location=Saint-Genouph |publisher=Nizet }} Two volumes were published, taking the edition up to 1861, but the editor's death brought the project to a halt.{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/correspondance/edition/ |title=Correspondance: Édition électronique |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 November 2017 |website=Correspondence de Flaubert |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |access-date=29 July 2018 }} A freely available Web-based edition comprising 4481 letters, 134 of which have not previously been published.{{sfn|Leclerc|Girard|2017}}{{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/jet/public/correspondance/feuilletage.php?t=I |title=Correspondance de Flaubert - Lettres Inédites |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 November 2017 |website=Correspondence: Édition électronique |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |access-date=3 August 2018 }} There have also been many single-correspondent editions of Flaubert's letters to one or another of his friends and associates, and selections from the collected letters.{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} == Translations == * {{cite book |last1=Tarver |first1=John Charles |year=1895 |title=Gustave Flaubert: As Seen in his Works and Correspondence |location=Westminster |publisher=A. Constable }} The first selection of the letters in English.{{sfn|Winock|2016|p=517}}{{cite web |url=https://scholarworks.uno.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1086&context=engl_facpubs |title=The Hermit of Croisset: Flaubert's Fiercely Enduring Perfectionism |last=Goodman |first=Richard |date=2009 |website=English Faculty Publications |publisher=University of New Orleans |page=4 |format=PDF |access-date=3 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |translator-last1=Mckenzie |translator-first1=Aimée L. |year=1922 |title=The George Sand – Gustave Flaubert Letters |location=London |publisher=Duckworth }}{{cite book |last1=Massardier-Kenney |first1=Françoise |author-link1=Françoise Massardier-Kenney |year=2000 |title=Gender in the Fiction of George Sand |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=p2BQq6dskAoC&pg=PA188&dq=%22flaubert+letters+london+duckworth%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjlnKOaydHcAhURLFAKHcFND6oQ6AEILTAB#v=onepage&q=%22flaubert%20letters%20london%20duckworth%22&f=false |location=Amsterdam |publisher=Rodopi |page=188 |isbn=9042007079 |access-date=3 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |translator-last1=Cohen |translator-first1=J. M. |translator-link1=J. M. Cohen |year=1950 |editor1-last=Rumbold |editor1-first=Richard |title=Gustave Flaubert: Letters |location=London |publisher=Weidenfeld and Nicolson }} Includes 122 letters.{{cite journal |last1=Cranston |first1=Maurice |author-link1=Maurice Cranston |date=12 May 1950 |title=Flaubert's Letters |url=http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/12th-may-1950/26/flauberts-letters |journal=The Spectator |page=26 |access-date=29 July 2018 }} * {{cite book |year=1954 |editor1-last=Steegmuller |editor1-first=Francis |editor1-link=Francis Steegmuller |title=The Selected Letters of Gustave Flaubert |location=London |publisher=Hamish Hamilton }} According to ''[[The Nation]]'', Steegmuller "edited them with discretion after translating them with authority".{{cite book |year=1977 |editor1-last=Sypher |editor1-first=F. J. |title=The Reader's Adviser: A Layman's Guide to Literature. Volume 2 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=NXg0AAAAMAAJ&q=%22epistolary+literature+and+Francis%22&dq=%22epistolary+literature+and+Francis%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjXk-Cs7NHcAhXKKcAKHXQyB1IQ6AEIJzAA |edition=12th |location=New York |publisher=Bowker |page=213 |isbn=0835208524 |access-date=3 August 2018 }}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1972 |editor1-last=Steegmuller |editor1-first=Francis |title=Flaubert in Egypt: A Sensibility on Tour. A Narrative Drawn from Gustave Flaubert's Travel Notes and Letters |location=Boston |publisher=Little, Brown }}{{sfn|Porter|2001|p=354}} * {{cite book |year=1979–1982 |editor1-last=Steegmuller |editor1-first=Francis |title=The Letters of Gustave Flaubert |location=Cambridge, Mass. |publisher=Belknap Press of Harvard University Press }} In two volumes. Jean Bruneau, editor of the then half-completed Pléiade edition, gave Steegmuller unfettered access to all his files, including the manuscripts of newly-discovered letters, with the result that some appeared in Steegmuller's English before they had been published in the original French. Its publication, ''[[The Times]]'' later said, "was a major event in the English-speaking literary world".{{cite news |author= |title=Francis Steegmuller |work=The Times |location=London |date=27 October 1994 |page=21 }}{{sfn|Barnes|2003}}{{cite book |last1=Patton |first1=Susannah |year=2010 |title=A Journey into Flaubert's Normandy |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=f36b0lAi0aMC&pg=PA248&dq=%22Press+1979+The+Letters+of+Gustave%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjlzvzsgtTcAhUFAsAKHYHeADoQ6AEILTAB#v=onepage&q=%22Press%201979%20The%20Letters%20of%20Gustave%22&f=false |location=Surry Hills, NSW |publisher=Accessible Publishing Systems |page=248 |isbn=9781458785435 |access-date=4 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |year=1985 |editor1-last=Beaumont |editor1-first=Barbara |title=Flaubert and Turgenev, a Friendship in Letters. The Complete Correspondence |location=London |publisher=Athlone }}{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=76}} * {{cite book |translator-last1=Steegmuller |translator-first1=Francis |translator-last2=Bray |translator-first2=Barbara |translator-link2=Barbara Bray |year=1993 |title=Flaubert-Sand: The Correspondence |location=New York |publisher=Alfred A. Knopf }} Includes about 100 letters not to be found in the 1922 Mckenzie translation. Barbara Bray translated George Sand's letters, and Francis Steegmuller Flaubert's. It has been called "a graceful and expressive translation in a scrupulous edition that has the effect of the best kind of biography – and a double one at that."{{cite news |last=Fields |first=Beverly |date=7 March 1993 |title=Flaubert and Sand: Linked by Excellence |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1993-03-07/entertainment/9303188035_1_flaubert-and-sand-flaubert-sand-suffrage |work=Chicago Tribune |access-date=4 August 2018 }}{{cite news |last=Shattuck |first=Roger |author-link=Roger Shattuck |date=21 February 1993 |title=Pen Pals par Excellence |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/02/21/books/pen-pals-par-excellence.html |work=New York Times |access-date=4 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |translator-last1=Wall |translator-first1=Geoffrey |year=1997 |title=Selected Letters |location=Baltimore |publisher=Penguin }}{{sfn|Porter|2001|p=355}} == Footnotes == {{Reflist|2}} == References == * {{cite book |last1=Barnes |first1=Julian |year=2002 |orig-year=2001 |title=Something to Declare |location=Leicester |publisher=W F Howes |isbn=1841975435 }} * {{cite news |last=Barnes |first=Julian |date=28 June 2003 |title=Worlds Within Words |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2003/jun/28/classics.julianbarnes |work=The Guardian |location=London |access-date=2 August 2018 }} * {{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/article.php?id=12 |title=Correspondance de Gustave Flaubert: Bibliographie des éditions et des études (1884–2013) |last=Cléroux |first=Gilles |date=2013 |website=Gustave Flaubert |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |language=French |access-date=2 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |last1=Le Calvez |first1=Eric J |year=2001 |chapter=Correspondance |editor1-last=Porter |editor1-first=Laurence M |title=A Gustave Flaubert Encyclopedia |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0La_MdsveVoC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |location=Westport, Conn. |publisher=Greenwood Press |isbn=031330744X |access-date=2 August 2018 }} * {{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/correspondance/edition/ |title=Correspondence de Flaubert |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 {{Refimprove|date=August 2014}} In [[printing]] and [[publishing]], '''proofs''' are the preliminary versions of publications meant for review by authors, editors, and proofreaders, often with extra-wide margins. '''Galley proofs''' may be uncut and unbound, or in some cases [[electronic publishing|electronically transmitted]]. They are created for [[proofreading]] and [[copyediting]] purposes, but may also be used for promotional and review purposes.<ref name="Tapia"/><ref name="TFD"/><ref name="TR"/> [[File:MS A la recherche du temps perdu.jpg|thumb| First galley proof of ''A la recherche du temps perdu: Du côté de chez Swann'' with handwritten revision notes by [[Marcel Proust]]]] [[File:Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Heart Mountain, Wyoming. In the press room of the Cody Enterprise . . . - NARA - 539218.jpg|thumb|[[Bill Hosokawa]] pulling a galley proof while working as a newspaper editor in the [[Heart Mountain Relocation Center|Heart Mountain concentration camp]], 1943]]
== Historical galley proofs ==
'''Proof,''' in the typographical sense, is a term that dates from c. 1600.<ref name="OED"/> The primary goal of proofing is to create a tool for verification that the job is accurate. All needed or suggested changes are physically marked on paper proofs or electronically marked on electronic proofs by the author, editor, and proofreaders. The [[typesetter|compositor, typesetter]], or printer receives the edited copies, corrects and re-arranges the type or the pagination, and arranges for the press workers to print the final or published copies.
'''Galley proofs''' or '''galleys''' are so named because in the days of hand-set [[letterpress printing]] in the 1650s, the printer would set the page into galleys, namely the metal trays into which type was laid and tightened into place.<ref name="OED.galley"/> A small proof press would then be used to print a limited number of copies for [[proofreading]].<ref name="OED.galley"/> Galley proofs are thus, historically speaking, galleys printed on a proof press.
From the printer's point of view, the galley proof, as it originated during the era of hand-set physical type, had two primary purposes, those being to check that the compositor had set the copy accurately (because sometimes individual pieces of type did get put in the wrong case after use) and that the type was free of defects (because type metal is comparatively soft, so type can get damaged).
Once a defect-free galley proof was produced, the publishing house requested a number of galley proofs to be run off for distribution to editors and authors for a final reading and corrections to the text before the type was fixed in the chase for printing.
== Uncorrected proofs ==
An uncorrected proof is a proof version (on paper or in digital form) which is yet to receive final author and publisher approval. The term may also appear on the covers of advance reading copies; see below.
These days, because much typesetting and pre-press work is conducted digitally and transmitted electronically, the term uncorrected proof is more common than the older term galley proof, which refers exclusively to a paper proofing system. However, if a paper print-out of an uncorrected proof is made on a desk-top printer or copy machine and used as a paper proof for authorial or editorial mark-up, it approximates a galley proof, and it may be referred to as a galley.
Preliminary electronic proof versions are also sometimes called '''digital proofs,''' '''pdf proofs,''' and '''pre-fascicle''' proofs, the last because they are viewed as single pages, not as they will look when gathered into fascicles or signatures for the press.<ref name="Knuth"/>
== Final proofs ==
Proofs created by the printer for approval by the publisher before going to press are called '''final proofs.''' At this stage in production, all mistakes are supposed to have been corrected and the pages are set up in imposition for folding and cutting on the press. To correct a mistake at this stage entails an extra cost per page, so authors are discouraged from making many changes to final proofs, while last-minute corrections by the in-house publishing staff may be accepted.
In the final proof stage, page layouts are examined closely. Additionally, because final page proofs contain the final [[pagination]], if an index was not compiled at an earlier stage in production, this pagination facilitates compiling a book's [[index (publishing)|index]] and correcting its table of contents.
== Advance reading copies ==
Historically, some publishers have used paper galley proofs as [[advance copy|advance copies or advance reading copies]] (ARCs) or as pre-publication publicity proofs. These are provided to reviewers, magazines, and libraries in advance of final publication. These galleys are not sent out for correction, but to ensure timely reviews of newly published works. The list of recipients designated by the publisher limits the number of copies to only what is required, making advance copies a form of [[print-on-demand]] (POD) publication.
Pre-publication publicity proofs are normally gathered and bound in paper, but in the case of books with four-color printed illustrations, publicity proofs may be lacking illustrations or have them in black and white only.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} They may be marked or stamped on the cover "uncorrected proof," but the recipient is not expected to proofread them, merely to overlook any minor errors of typesetting.
Galley proofs in electronic form are rarely used as advance reading copies due to the possibility of a recipient editing the proof and issuing it as their own. However, trusted colleagues are occasionally offered electronic advance reading copies, especially if the publisher wishes to quickly typeset a page or two of "advance praise" notices within the book itself.
==See also== *[[Composing stick]] *[[Prepress proofing|Prepress color proofing]]

Knuth]] in describing early pre-production versions of the [[fascicle (book)|fascicle]]s of his work ''[[The Art of Computer Programming]]''.</ref> }}
