revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Notability|Prof|date=May 2014}} {{BLP sources|date=May 2014}} {{COI|date=May 2014}} {{Orphan|date=April 2017}} }} '''Jerome "Jerry" Balmuth''' (May 8, 1924 - September 28, 2017) was an [[United States|American]] [[philosopher]] and the Harry Emerson Fosdick Professor of Philosophy and Religion, Emeritus, at [[Colgate University]] in [[Hamilton, New York]].{{cite web|title=Jerome Balmuth|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/uticaod/obituary.aspx?pid=186821402|publisher=The Observer-Dispatch|accessdate=12 November 2017}} == Early life == Balmuth developed his interest in philosophy after high school, when he enrolled in a philosophy night course at the [[City College of New York]]. In 1944 he joined the [[United States Army]] and was assigned to a [[Signal Corps (United States Army)|Signal Corps]] unit. He subsequently attended [[Officer Candidate School (United States Army)|officer candidate school]] and was commissioned as a second lieutenant, transferring to the military police. In 1948 he was discharged at the rank of first lieutenant. Balmuth then attended [[Amherst College]] on the [[G.I. Bill]]. After graduating [[Phi Beta Kappa]] and [[magna cum laude]] from Amherst, Balmuth entered graduate school at [[Cornell University]], where he held a Sage Fellowship, and later, a [[Danforth Fellowship]].{{cite web|last=Frank|first=Gary|title=An Extended Season of Deeds|url=http://www4.colgate.edu/scene/july2004/balmuth.html|work=The Colgate Scene|publisher=Colgate University}}
{{cite book|last=Freedman|first=Robert|title=Marxist Social Thought|date=1968|publisher=Harcourt Brace|location=New York|page=Introduction}}
{{cite web|last=Balmuth|first=Jerome|title=The Illusion of Sameness|url=http://colgate.imodules.com/s/801/scene_inside_2col.aspx?id=801&gid=1&pgid=2581|work=The Colgate Scene|publisher=Colgate University|accessdate=Spring 2010}} == Academic career == In 1954, Balmuth joined the faculty at Colgate, where he commenced a 50+ year teaching career. Balmuth specialized in [[Wittgenstein]]'s philosophy and influence, [[history of philosophy]], [[religion]], [[aesthetics]], ([[mathematical logic|symbolic]] and advanced), [[philosophy of law]], [[philosophy of logic]], [[meta-ethics]] and their connection with the [[philosophy of language]].{{cite web|last=Balmuth|first=Jerome |title=Colgate Faculty Directory |url=http://www.colgate.edu/facultysearch/facultydirectory/jbalmuth |publisher=Colgate University}} == Recognition == During his career, Balmuth received all four Colgate teaching awards: Alumni Corporation Distinguished Teaching Award, AAUP Professor of the Year, Phi Eta Sigma Professor of the Year Award and the Samuel French Award. The Jerome Balmuth Endowed Fund, established in 2000, provides annual support to attract visiting lecturers on philosophy to Colgate. The Jerome Balmuth Scholarship Fund, established in 2004, provides academic awards with a preference for a philosophy major. In 2009, Colgate established the Jerome Balmuth Award for Teaching and Student-Faculty Engagement. == Works == Balmuth's published works include his contributions to ''Marxist Social Thought'' (1968) and articles in ''[[Mind (journal)|Mind]]''. == References == {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Balmuth, Jerry}} [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:20th-century American philosophers]] [[Category:American logicians]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:Amherst College alumni]] [[Category:Colgate University faculty]] [[Category:Cornell University alumni]] [[Category:American historians of philosophy]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:Philosophers of art]] [[Category:Philosophers of language]] [[Category:Wittgensteinian philosophers]] [[Category:Philosophers from New York (state)]]

{{Essay-like|date=November 2018}} '''Jolie laide''' (English translation: "beautiful ugly") is the French expression used to describe someone who is unconventionally beautiful. Snaggle teeth, a bump in the nose, closely set eyes are just a few examples of unconventional physical traits, which some might view as deformities, that are embraced under the notion of jolie laide. Although the concept of jolie laide recognizes that ''men act and women appear'' (as the writer John Berger once put it), it also recognizes that behind the visceral image lies an internal life.<ref name="nytimes">{{cite web|last=Merkin|first=Daphne|title=The Unfairest of Them All|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/16/style/tmagazine/t_b_2122_talk_jolie_laide_.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|publisher=New York Times|date=16 October 2005|accessdate=1 December 2012}}</ref> As the literary critic Daphne Merkin put it, jolie laide is "a triumph of personality over physiognomy, the imposition of substance over surface."<ref name="nytimes" />
It is unclear when and where the term arose in French culture. Some have surmised that the term comes out of Serge Gainsbourg's song "Laide Jolie Laide."<ref name="Ollivier 272">{{cite book|last=Ollivier|first=Debra|title=What French Women Know: About Love, Sex, and Other Matters of the Heart and Mind|year=2010|publisher=Berkley Trade|location=USA|isbn=042523648X|pages=272}}</ref>
Celebrities commonly thought to encapsulate this notion include: [[Anjelica Huston]] whose "regal asymmetry defies the norms of magazine 'pretty'";<ref>{{cite book|last=Ollivier|first=Debra|title=What French Women Know: About Love, Sex, and Other Matters of the Heart and Mind|year=2010|publisher=Berkley Trade|location=USA|isbn=042523648X}}</ref> [[Sofia Coppola]] with her "introspective, girl-in-a-Vermeer-painting aura rather than the paint-by-numbers cheerleader vibe of Lindsay Lohan.";<ref name="nytimes" /> [[Charlotte Gainsbourg]] with her "melancholic air and the vaguely awkward way she inhabits her lanky body".<ref name="Ollivier 272" /> The late [[Isabella Blow]] has also been described by this term.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nymag.com/news/features/34732/?ref=fashion|title=The Sad Hatter|last=Larocca|first=Amy|date=15 May 2007|publisher=''New York Magazine''}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Beauty]] [[Category:French words and phrases]] [[Category:Interpersonal attraction]]

page.title: List of K-pop music videos banned by Korean television networks

revision.text:
The following is a non-exhaustive list of [[K-pop]] videos that have been banned by South Korean television networks, for reasons such as suggestive or offensive lyrics and imagery.
K-pop is a genre of modern [[pop music]] that originates from [[South Korea]]. It is characterized by a wide variety of audiovisual elements, and K-pop singles will typically include a music video and a dance routine. There is a history of media [[censorship in South Korea|censorship]] and [[conservatism in South Korea]], and as a result, many risque or explicit K-pop songs or videos have been banned by South Korean broadcasting stations. Other reasons for banning include having Japanese lyrics, negatively influencing youth, or use of brand names.
[[Korean Broadcasting System|KBS]], [[Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation|MBC]], and [[Seoul Broadcasting System|SBS]] are the three largest broadcasting and television networks, and they account for the vast majority of banned K-pop videos. In September 2012, it was revealed that these networks had banned over 1,300 K-pop songs in the past three years alone.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kpopstarz.com/articles/89575/20140430/what-it-takes-to-get-a-song-banned-from-broadcast-stations-in-korea.htm|title=What It Takes To Get A Song Banned From Broadcast Stations In Korea|last=KpopStarz|date=2014-04-30|work=KpopStarz|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref> This list only includes titular k-pop songs that have an accompanying music video, but many K-pop songs that were not title tracks have been banned as well.
== List of banned K-pop videos == {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ !Song Title !Artist !Reason !Banned By |- |[[Gentleman (Psy song)|"Gentleman"]] |[[Psy|PSY]] |Showing destruction of public property.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2013/04/18/south-korean-tv-network-bans-psys-gentleman-music-video/|title=South Korean TV Network Bans Psy’s ‘Gentleman’ Music Video|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> |KBS |- |"[[Catallena]]" |[[Orange Caramel]] |"Devaluing human life" by having the members be wrapped in plastic packages.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.soompi.com/2014/03/21/kbs-rules-that-orange-carmels-catellena-mv-has-scene-that-disregards-human-life/|title=KBS Rules That Orange Caramel's "Catellena" MV Has Scene That "Disregards Human Life" {{!}} Soompi|website=www.soompi.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Turn It Up" |[[T.O.P (rapper)|T.O.P.]] |Indirect advertisement.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dkpopnews.net/2010/07/mbc-has-banned-tops-song-turn-it-up.html|title=[News] MBC banned TOP's Turn it up|work=Daily K Pop News|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> |MBC |- |"Joker" |[[Dal Shabet]] |Title is similar to crude Korean word for male genitalia, as well as explicit dance moves.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.inquisitr.com/2042948/dai-shabet-why-was-k-pop-groups-new-music-video-joker-banned-video/|title=Dal Shabet: Why Was K-Pop Group’s New Music Video ‘Joker’ Banned? [Video]|date=2015-04-25|work=The Inquisitr|access-date=2018-05-08|language=en-US}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Marionette" |[[Stellar (South Korean band)|Stellar]] |Explicit dance moves.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2014/02/12/2014021202634.html|title=엉덩이로 방아 찧고 돌린 ‘스텔라’ 19禁 판정…"쉿! 케이블에선 다 보여줄게"|access-date=2018-03-26|language=ko}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Uh-ee" |[[Crayon Pop]] |Use of a Japanese word.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/korearealtime/2014/04/03/crayon-pops-uh-ee-banned-for-shiny-japanese-word/|title=Crayon Pop’s ‘Uh-ee’ Banned for Shiny Japanese Word|last=Gale|first=Alastair|date=2014-04-03|website=WSJ|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Island" |[[Winner (band)|WINNER]] |Homosexual imagery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2017/08/17/kbs-bans-winners-island-due-homosexuality-imagery|title=KBS bans WINNER's 'Island' due to "homosexuality" imagery|website=SBS PopAsia|language=en|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Love Don't Hurt" |[[Shannon (South Korean singer)|Shannon]] |Imagery of nudity, tattoos, and smoking.<ref>{{Cite broadcast due to nudity, tattoos, and smoking|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Dreaming i" |[[F.Cuz|F.CUZ]] |Rebellious plot that could be a negative influence for broadcast|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Beep" |[[Park Ji-yoon|Park Ji Yoon]] |Excessive ending credit roll.<ref name=":0">{{Cite broadcast by KBS|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Pass Me By" |[[Brown Eyed Girls]] |Use of trademark or brand names.<ref name=":0" /> |KBS |- |"I'll Call Ya" |[[M.O.A.]] |Poor SBS|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref> |KBS, MBC, SBS |- |"Bad Girls" |[[Lee Hyori]] |Problematic scenes including a student using a slingshot and a teacher who sexually assaults the students.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2013/05/kbs-deems-lee-hyoris-bad-girls-mv-inappropriate-for-broadcast|title=KBS deems Lee Hyori's "Bad Girls" MV inappropriate for broadcast|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Angel" |Hoya |Lyrics depicts sexual intercourse between a man and a woman.<ref>{{Cite broadcast|last=|first=|date=|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Instagram" |[[Dean (South Korean singer)|DEAN]] |Use of the [[Instagram]] brand name.<ref>{{Cite |- |"DDD" |[[EXID]] |Cursing, derogatory terms, and indecent language in lyrics.<ref>{{Cite broadcast|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Chitty Chitty Bang Bang" |Lee Hyori |Depiction of traffic violations—driving without a seatbelt on, dancing on top of buses and in roads.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2010/04/lee-hyoris-chitty-chitty-bang-bang-mv-gets-banned|title=Lee Hyori's Chitty Chitty Bang Bang MV gets banned|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |- |"How Dare You" |[[Sistar|SISTAR]] |Pole dance move and belittling lyrics.<ref>{{Cite |[[Block B]] |Lyrics describing unwholesome dating methods. It was banned twice, after the lyrics were edited.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2011/08/block-bs-freeze-gets-banned-for-the-second-time-without-an-explanation|title=Block B's "Freeze!" gets banned for the second time without an explanation|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Paradise Lost" |[[Gain (singer)|Gain]] |Provocative dance moves.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/k-town/6531811/gain-hawwah-interview-religion-south-korea|title=Gain Goes In on New 'Hawwah' EP, Religion and South Korea's Conservative Music Industry|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS, MBC, SBS |- |"[[Lotto (song)|Lotto]]" |[[Exo (band)|EXO]] |Title is a brand name.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.soompi.com/2016/08/16/exo-changes-title-track-lotto-kbs-mbc-promotions/|title=EXO Changes Title Track "Lotto" For KBS And MBC Promotions {{!}} Soompi|website=www.soompi.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS, MBC |- |"Cherry Bomb" |[[NCT (band)|NCT 127]] |Violent lyrics. Banned again after reconsideration.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://v.entertain.media.daum.net/v/20170621150651845|title=NCT127 '체리밤' KBS 재심의서 또 부적격 판정|date=20170621150650|work=다음 연예|access-date=2018-05-09|language=ko}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Fxxk It" |[[Big Bang (South Korean band)|Big Bang]] |Inappropriate lyrics, including slang.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://kpopherald.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=201612211717343099190_2|title=KBS bans Big Bang’s ‘Fxxk It’ for ‘inappropriate’ lyrics|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Udon" |Kang Min Kyung & Son Dong Woon |Use of a Japanese word for the title.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2010/12/kang-minkyung-dongwoons-udon-single-deemed-unfit-for-broadcast|title=Kang Minkyung, Dongwoon's 'Udon' single deemed 'unfit' for broadcast|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |- |"[[Boombayah]]" |[[Black Pink|BLACKPINK]] |Inappropriate lyrics and mentioning [[Hennessy|an alcohol brand]].<ref name=":1" /> |KBS |- |"Rocket Girl" |Stellar |Violence and sexually suggestive content.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2011/08/kbs-bans-stellars-debut-mv-rocket-girl-for-violence-and-sexually-suggestive-content|title=KBS bans Stellar's debut MV, "Rocket Girl", for violence and sexually suggestive content|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |- |"We Like to Party" |Big Bang |Indirect advertisement and profanity.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2015/06/04/bigbang-release-we-2-party-music-video|title=BIGBANG release "We Like 2 Party" music video|website=SBS PopAsia|language=en|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |- |"One More" |[[Fiestar|FIESTAR]] |Lyrics alluding to sexual activity with three people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.soompi.com/2014/07/09/fiestars-one-more-banned-by-mbc-for-threesome-references/#.U74HcI3M1QZ|title=FIESTAR's "One More" Banned by MBC for Threesome References {{!}} Soompi|website=www.soompi.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |MBC |- |"Fly" |[[Jessica Jung|Jessica]] |Use of brand names.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2016/05/jessicas-new-song-fly-banned-on-kbs|title=Jessica's new song 'Fly' banned on KBS|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Full House" |MOBB |Use of brand name, derogatory remarks, and mention of drunk driving.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2016/09/kbs-bans-all-of-mobbs-songs-except-for-hit-me|title=KBS bans all of MOBB's songs except for 'Hit Me'|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Body" |Minho |Use of brand name.<ref name=":2" /> |KBS |- |"HOLUP!" |Bobby |Cursing, derogatory terms, Japanese lyrics, uses of brand names, and alcohol abuse.<ref name=":2" /> |KBS |- |"January" |[[Beenzino]] |Reference to Facebook.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2016/07/hyuna-fei-heize-and-beenzinos-new-tracks-banned-by-kbs|title=HyunA, Fei, Heize, and Beenzino's new tracks banned by KBS|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Dope" |[[BTS (band)|BTS]] |Vulgar lyrics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2016/05/six-of-btss-new-songs-deemed-unfit-for-broadcast|title=Six of BTS's songs from new album deemed unfit for broadcast|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |- |"Oh NaNa" |[[Kard (band)|K.A.R.D.]] |Mention of Instagram.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://enter.etoday.co.kr/view/news_view.php?varAtcId=89018|title=DSP 측 "K.A.R.D ‘오나나’, 재녹음 후 다시 KBS 심의 신청"|date=2016-12-08|work=비즈엔터|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> |KBS |}
== Aftermath of bans ==
=== Revising === Often, the entertainment company that owns the banned song will try to revise the song and have its reevaluated by the broadcasting company. They may edit the music video and delete the controversial scenes and re-release the new video. Other times, they may alter the explicit dance moves or change a song's lyrics so that the song may still be performed on music shows, such as [[Music Bank (TV series)|Music Bank.]] In the case of EXO's "Lotto," which as banned due to the title being a brand name, the group sang the word "louder" instead of "lotto" while performing the song live. This revision allowed the song to be performed on KBS and MBC music shows.<ref name=":1" />
Although K-pop songs and videos are often banned by KBS, is it less often for MBC or SBS to place a ban. Some groups are content to promote themselves on networks other than KBS and do not make any changes to their original material. In regards to PSY's "Gentlemen," a spokesperson for YG Entertainment said they had no plans to submit a difference version of their video, and they followed the decision made by KBS.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/korearealtime/2013/04/18/south-korean-tv-network-bans-psys-video/|title=South Korean TV Network Bans Psy’s Video|last=Kwaak|first=Jeyup S.|date=2013-04-18|website=WSJ|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref>
When 12 out of 18 songs of [[Cheetah (rapper)|Cheetah]]'s album were deemed unfit for broadcast by KBS and five by SBS, the agency stated that they did not plan on making any changes to the lyrics in order to "keep the original intentions and meanings of the song."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2018/02/12-songs-in-cheetahs-new-album-deemed-unfit-for-kbs-agency-says-no-changes-will-be-made-in-lyrics|title=12 songs in Cheetah's new album deemed unfit for KBS + agency says no changes will be made in lyrics|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref>
=== Fan reactions === Of all the broadcasting networks, KBS has banned the most songs and videos, earning it the nickname "Korean Banning System." When a more explicit video is released, fans have come to expect the video to be deemed inappropriate for broadcast by KBS.
There have been cases of fans arguing against a banning decision. When KBS deemed several of Block B's new songs as being unfit for broadcast, an online petition appeared, requesting that KBS reconsider their decision. It gained 2,400 signatures within a day.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2012/01/kbs-deems-block-bs-new-songs-unfit-for-broadcast|title=KBS deems Block B's new songs unfit for broadcast|work=allkpop|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref>
== See also ==
* [[Censorship of Japanese media in South Korea]]
==References== <references />
[[Category:Lists of songs]] [[Category:Lists of music videos]] [[Category:Lists of musical works]] [[Category:Korean Broadcasting System]] [[Category:Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation]] [[category:Seoul Broadcasting System]] [[category:Censorship in South Korea]] [[Category:Censorship of music]] [[Category:K-pop]]

page.title: List of Sweet Valley High books

revision.text:
This is a list of books in the ''[[Sweet Valley High]]'' series, created by [[Francine Pascal]]. There are 181 books in total.
== Books== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! # !! Title !! Author !! Publisher !! Date
{{Book list | book_number = 1 | title = ''Double Love'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 1, 1984 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth Wakefield really likes Todd Wilkins and he likes her but her twin sister Jessica wants Todd for herself. Also, speculation is rampant about Marianna West, a lawyer in Mr. Wakefield's law firm. }} {{Book list | book_number = 2 | title = ''Secrets'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 1, 1984 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Liz's best friend Enid has a secret that she's terrified will make her boyfriend leave her, and rumor-spreading Jessica makes sure that is just what happens. Liz tries to fix everything and succeeds when Todd finds out Jessica's own secret from Cara. Meanwhile, jealous Lila Fowler starts a rumor about French teacher Nora Dalton, whom her father George has been dating. At the dance, Enid admits to Liz that she was glad that Jessica made her see Roger for the jerk he is. She was a helping hand for Enid in reconciling her friendship with George. In the end, Jessica and Lila get their comeuppance. }} {{Book list | book_number = 3 | title = ''Playing With Fire'' | author = Kate William | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 1, 1984 | line_color = novel | short_summary = At long last, Jessica is finally dating Bruce Patman! Unfortunately, she is changing her whole personality to fit in with what Bruce wants; Liz worries about this and also that Bruce is too fast. However when Jessica discovers Bruce cheating on her with another girl, she gets her revenge on him by throwing pizza on both his and his date's clothes. Meanwhile, could Sweet Valley High's own rock band, The Droids, be headed for the big time? }} {{Book list | book_number = 4 | title = ''Power Play'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = December 1, 1984 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Chubby Robin Wilson wants to join SVH sorority Pi Beta Alpha and Liz nominates her, but furious Jessica and her conniving friends do everything they can to keep her out while Liz does her best to get her in. But when Robin gets [[blackballing|blackballed]], she realized the only person who cared about her as a friend was Liz. So she gets her revenge on the Pi Betas by not only losing weight, but also taking the Homecoming queen nomination from Jessica. Also, wealthy Lila Fowler tries to get her absentee father's attention by shoplifting. When Liz finds out about Jessica being arrested for shoplifting and confronts Lila, she learns the truth about Lila's strained relationship with her parents, along with the fact that she considers Liz: her true friend because she always put others before herself. When Liz asks about Jessica, Lila admits her dislike for the latter for how she mistreats others and how bad she felt for Robin. Mr. Fowler shows up to clarify everything. }} {{Book list | book_number = 5 | title = ''All Night Long'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 1, 1984 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica starts dating experienced college student Scott Daniels. After their late night she pleads with Liz to take a test for her, which infuriates her and gets her into a fight with Todd. }} {{Book list | book_number = 6 | title = ''Dangerous Love'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = | line_color = novel | short_summary = Todd gets a motorcycle and Liz's parents forbid her to ride on it with him because of her cousin's motorcycle-related death. She disobeys--with disastrous consequences. }} {{Book list | book_number = 7 | title = ''Dear Sister'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = November 1, 1984 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Liz wakes up from a coma following her accident and has turned into ... Jessica. She dumps Todd and starts flirting madly and indiscriminantly with other guys. Jessica desperately wants her twin back. }} {{Book list | book_number = 8 | title = ''Heartbreaker'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = November 1, 1984 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica loves leading on Bill Chase, who once turned her down for a date, but is now falling for her, and Jessica's dazzle blinds him to DeeDee Gordon's genuine crush on him. So Liz helps DeeDee out by exposing Jessica to Bill and leading him to dump her }} {{Book list | book_number = 9 | title = ''Racing Hearts'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = July 13, 1999 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Roger Barrett is a great runner, and when he wins a school competition Lila Fowler shows interest. Jessica gets a job in her father's law firm. }} {{Book list | book_number = 10 | title = ''Wrong Kind of Girl'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 7, 1999 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Annie Whitman wants to join the cheerleading squad, but Jessica doesn't want "easy" Annie anywhere near; her reputation might affect the squad. So when Annie nearly attempts suicide and Liz reprimands her, Jessica grudgingly agrees to let Annie join. }} {{Book list | book_number = 11 | title = ''Too Good To Be True'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = December 1, 1984 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Suzanne Devlin, the daughter of one of Mr. Wakefield's college friends, has come to stay at the Wakefields' while Jessica goes to New York to stay with the Devlins. She manages to charm everybody, except English teacher Roger Collins and Elizabeth(who suspected her devious side). When she hits on him and he doesn't respond, she lets her truly diabolical side rule and accuses him of assault and Liz must expose her treachery and help save Mr. Collins' reputation. She succeeds with the help of Winston Egbert who tricks Suzanne into making a video tape confession of her scheme. This humiliates Suzanne and she is sent home to New York to face proper punishment by her parents. }} {{Book list | book_number = 12 | title = ''When Love Dies'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = October 1, 1984 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Steven Wakefield discovers why his girlfriend Tricia Martin has seemed distant lately. Jessica tries again to get him interested in her friend Cara, but Elizabeth warns her to behave herself. The twins are candy-stripers at the local hospital. }} {{Book list | book_number = 13 | title = ''Kidnapped!'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = December 1, 1999 | line_color = novel | short_summary = A disturbed orderly named Carl kidnaps Liz from the hospital. Meanwhile, Max Dellon of Sweet Valley High's own band, The Droids, is arrested for the crime and everyone is pinning their blame on him. However, Jessica believes in his innocence and puts her scheming ways to good use by posing as Elizabeth. Her plan works well as she attends work as her sister. When Carl sees her as Liz, he is fooled into believing he had wrongly kidnapped Jessica. After he is caught by the police, Liz and Max show their gratitude towards her. }} {{Book list | book_number = 14 | title = ''Deceptions'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = November 1, 1984 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica has fallen for Nicholas Morrow, but he has eyes for Liz - who is already spoken for. }} {{Book list | book_number = 15 | title = ''Promises'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = December 1, 1984 | line_color = novel | short_summary = After Tricia Martin dies, her troubled dropout sister Betsy stays with the Wakefields, to Jessica's dismay. Winston Egbert tries to break a pizza-eating record. }} {{Book list | book_number = 16 | title = ''Rags to Riches'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = January 1, 1985 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Roger Barrett is a Patman! It turns out Roger's father was Bruce's uncle Paul. When Roger's mother dies, Roger goes to live with the Patmans. His uncle Henry welcomes him, but Bruce and his mother snub him. Meanwhile, Jessica tries to get between Roger and his girlfriend Olivia. }} {{Book list | book_number = 17 | title = ''Love Letters'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = February 1, 1985 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Gossipy Caroline Pearce wants to be accepted, so she invents love letters to prove that she's got a boyfriend, and she actually stirs up others' interest in her relationship - too bad it's fake! Meanwhile, the twins think their parents want to move to San Francisco. Elizabeth then discovers that Caroline is lonely and has no friends at school, being continuously shunned. After befriending her, Liz encourages her to be herself. Caroline changes her ways for the better due to Elizabeth's friendship. }} {{Book list | book_number = 18 | title = ''Head Over Heels'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = March 1, 1985 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Bruce Patman and Regina Morrow fall in love. Regina, deaf since birth, learns of a treatment that may restore her hearing - but she'd have to stay in Switzerland for a year. She is finally happy with her Sweet Valley life, but what if she could actually hear? }} {{Book list | book_number = 19 | title = ''Showdown'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 1, 1985 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Frenemies Jessica and Lila clash over the mysterious Jack. }} {{Book list | book_number = 20 | title = ''Crash Landing!'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = May 1, 1985 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Enid and her boyfriend George are involved in a plane accident; Enid's injury - paralysis from the waist down - halts George from breaking up with her. Meanwhile, Jessica and Lila take a cooking course, mainly to drool over the scrumptious French chef. }} {{Book list | book_number = 21 | title = ''Runaway'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = June 1, 1985 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica is fed up with coming second to her twin and decides to run away with Nicky Shephard to San Francisco. Meanwhile, Elizabeth's friend Ricky Capaldo is dealing with his parents' divorce: his mother won't let his father's parents spend time with him and his little sister. }} {{Book list | book_number = 22 | title = ''Too Much In Love'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = August 1, 1985 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Bill and DeeDee clash over her clinginess. Elizabeth plans a talent show and gets the shock of her life. }} {{Book list | book_number = 23 | title = ''Say Goodbye'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 1, 1985 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Todd Wilkins is moving to Vermont and Liz dreads their farewell. Jessica gets a job at a dating agency and tries to find matches for her brother Steven. }} {{Book list | book_number = 24 | title = ''Memories'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = November 14, 2000 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Steven Wakefield and Cara Walker take steps toward falling in love, but Tricia Martin's sister Betsy tries to sabotage it. Elizabeth sees Cara in a more favorable light and they become friends, which strains Cara's friendship with Jessica. }} {{Book list | book_number = 25 | title = ''Nowhere to Run'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = December 1, 1985 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Mr. Wakefield's parents visit, and Emily Mayer turns to the Wakefield family for help coping with her impossible stepmother, whose side her father seems to be taking over hers. }} {{Book list | book_number = 26 | title = ''Hostage!'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = January 1, 1986 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Regina and her parents are held hostage; Liz, Nicholas and Bruce try to rescue them. }} {{Book list | book_number = 27 | title = ''Lovestruck'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = February 13, 2001 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Ken Matthews is in love with stuck-up, snobby Suzanne Hanlon and will do anything to keep her happy, even change his whole personality. }} {{Book list | book_number = 28 | title = ''Alone In the Crowd'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 1, 1986 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Painfully-shy Lynne Henry is a talented songwriter. She could possibly win a competition to write a song for The Droids - if she could be encouraged to enter. }} {{Book list | book_number = 29 | title = ''Bitter Rivals'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = June 1, 1986 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Liz's old best friend Amy Sutton moves back to Sweet Valley from Connecticut. Liz is psyched, but Amy and Enid don't get along. Amy becomes close friends with Jessica when Liz makes one of her hardest decisions to remain friends with Enid. }} {{Book list | book_number = 30 | title = ''Jealous Lies'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = August 1, 1986 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Sandra Bacon and Jean West's friendship is strained when Jeannie wants to pledge Pi Beta Alpha, which Sandy thinks is the only thing she has that "perfect" Jeannie doesn't, causing her to try to keep Jeannie out. Meanwhile, Steven alarms his family by considering leaving college. }} {{Book list | book_number = 31 | title = ''Taking Sides'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = October 01, 1986 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Lila and Enid are after the same guy, newcomer Jeffrey French. Jessica and Elizabeth become pimps for their respective friends, and when Jessica realizes that Jeffrey only has eyes for Elizabeth, she does whatever she can to sabotage Liz's chances with Jeffrey. The twins' cousin Jenny picks this time to visit. Jenny catches on Jessica's plans and uses her conniving ways against her. After Liz and Jeffrey learn the truth, Ned and Alice gets involved and ground Jessica. }} {{Book list | book_number = 32 | title = ''The New Jessica'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = November 01, 1986 | line_color = novel | short_summary = After being mistaken for Liz too many times, Jessica aspires to a more sophisticated image, dyes her hair black, and pursues a modeling career (as "Jessa Fields"). Liz is hurt and scared that she'll lose her best friend. When the modeling agency hires Liz to be their new model, Jessica decides it's better to be herself and dyes her hair back to its natural blonde color. }} {{Book list | book_number = 33 | title = ''Starting Over'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = August 14, 2001 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Dana Larson's cousin Sally moves in with her family. The Wakefields might also have a new addition. }} {{Book list | book_number = 34 | title = ''Forbidden Love'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 11, 2001 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Maria Santelli and Michael Harris are in love, but their families are definitely against their relationship. To show their parents that they're serious, they become engaged. }} {{Book list | book_number = 35 | title = ''Out of Control'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = February 1, 1987 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Aaron Dallas has problems dealing with his parents' divorce, and his anger alienates him from everyone in his life. Meanwhile, Jessica attempts to make some fast cash by selling Tofu-Glo cosmetics. }} {{Book list | book_number = 36 | title = ''Last Chance'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 1, 1987 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Amy Sutton falls for Peter DeHaven, who looks pretty good to Julie Porter's dropout older sister Johanna - good enough that she might consider dropping back into school. }} {{Book list | book_number = 37 | title = ''Rumors'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = May 1, 1987 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jealous Lila Fowler spreads a vindictive rumor about the myterious Susan Stewart, who lives with a guardian and knows nothing of her biological parents. }} {{Book list | book_number = 38 | title = ''Leaving Home'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = January 8, 2002 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth considers going to a prestigious writing school in Switzerland, and Jessica and Steven connive to keep her in California. }} {{Book list | book_number = 39 | title = ''Secret Admirer'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = August 1, 1987 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Penny Ayala, Liz's friend and editor of ''The Oracle'', decides to put a personal ad in the paper. It is answered by a guy who finds her interesting, but was actually pressured to respond as a joke by nasty Kirk Anderson and other guys. Kirk's scheme angers Elizabeth enough to strike back with a plan that would have made Jessica proud. }} {{Book list | book_number = 40 | title = ''On the Edge'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 1, 1987 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Regina thinks she and Bruce are happy, but scheming Amy Sutton has other ideas. Regina learns of Amy's betrayal at a party at the Wakefields' and storms off after confronting Amy, Bruce, and Liz. Feeling rejected, she turns to a new crowd who are into hard drugs.... }} {{Book list | book_number = 41 | title = ''Outcast'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 9, 2002 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Ever since Regina's death, people have been ostracizing Molly Hecht, blaming her for what happened. Even Liz finds not blaming Molly difficult. Eventually Liz and Molly's "only" friend Justin try to save Molly from making a terrible mistake. }} {{Book list | book_number = 42 | title = ''Caught in the Middle'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = December 1, 1987 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Sandra Bacon is in love with Manuel Lopez but her parents are narrow-minded racists. When Manuel is accused of being at the scene of an incident, Sandra is reluctant to provide him with an alibi as it will mean her parents will find out about her and Manuel. }} {{Book list | book_number = 43 | title = ''Hard Choices'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = January 1, 1988 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Enid's grandmother moves in with her and her mother. }} {{Book list | book_number = 44 | title = ''Pretenses'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = July 9, 2002 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Cara and Steven's relationship suffers through another unbelievable Jessica-engineered misunderstanding; Abbie Richardson, a former friend of Jessica's, becomes friends with Liz. }} {{Book list | book_number = 45 | title = ''Family Secrets'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 1, 1988 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jess and Liz's cousin Kelly visits and deals with angst from her parents' divorce. }} {{Book list | book_number = 46 | title = '' Decisions'' | author = Kate William | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = June 1st 1988 | line_color = novel | short_summary = When Robin Wilson's aunt offers to pay for her to attend college in New York, Robin is torn between being able to afford college and wanting to stay near Sweet Valley with George and go to a school where she can pursue her swimming. }} {{Book list | book_number = 47 | title = ''Troublemaker'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = October 8, 2002 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Bruce Patman has become his nasty self again and starts tormenting Phi Epsilon pledge Josh Bowen, which infuriates his friend Julie Porter. }} {{Book list | book_number = 48 | title = ''Slam Book Fever'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = November 12, 2002 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Soon after the slam book is introduced to Sweet Valley, there's 137 different kinds of confusion as to who's dating whom. Liz is worried that boyfriend Jeffrey wants to go out with her friend Olivia Davidson. Jess is falling for the new boy but Liz's reckless behaivior may ruin it. }} {{Book list | book_number = 49 | title = ''Playing for Keeps'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 1, 1988 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica must enter a fashion show to compete with a nasty girl named Pamela Janson who threatens to steal boyfriend A.J. from her. }} {{Book list | book_number = 50 | title = ''Out of Reach'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = October 1, 1988 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jade Wu wants to dance, but her strict traditionalist father disapproves. }} {{Book list | book_number = 51 | title = ''Against the Odds'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = December 1, 1988 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Ronnie Edwards has a gambling problem; Jessica tries her hand at selling homemade jewelry. }} {{Book list | book_number = 52 | title = ''White Lies'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = January 1, 1989 | line_color = novel | short_summary = John Pfeifer goes out with Jennifer Mitchell. }} {{Book list | book_number = 53 | title = ''Second Chance'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = February 1, 1989 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Tennis pro Kristin Thompson has a hard time dealing with her life choices. }} {{Book list | book_number = 54 | title = ''Two-Boy Weekend'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = | line_color = novel | short_summary = Since boyfriend A.J. is out of town for the weekend, Jessica sees no problem with going out with handsome Chris. But never underestimate karma - Jessica has trouble shaking Chris off after A.J. returns. }} {{Book list | book_number = 55 | title = ''Perfect Shot'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 1, 1989 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Shelley Novak: great at basketball, but dating ... not so much. Her longtime crush hardly notices her. Maybe school photographer can change her focus. }} {{Book list | book_number = 56 | title = ''Lost at Sea'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = May 1, 1989 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica and Winston get stranded after a class trip. }} {{Book list | book_number = 57 | title = ''Teacher Crush'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = July 1, 1989 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Olivia Davidson develops a crush on her art teacher, Stuart Bachman. }} {{Book list | book_number = 58 | title = ''Broken Hearted'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = August 1, 1989 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Todd Wilkins returns from Vermont and throws Liz's life into a tailspin. }} {{Book list | book_number = 59 | title = ''In Love Again'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 1, 1989 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Todd leaves his snotty private school, which Jessica insists on attending, and returns to SVH. He and Elizabeth rekindle their romance. }} {{Book list | book_number = 60 | title = ''That Fatal Night'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = October 1, 1989 | line_color = novel | short_summary = After being blinded in an accident, Ken Matthews gets dumped by shallow Amy Sutton, who just can't deal with a handicapped boyfriend. Ken eventually turns to football-team statistician Terri Adams. }} {{Book list | book_number = 61 | title = ''Boy Trouble'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = November 9, 1999 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Patty Gilbert is having a relationship problem with her boyfriend Jim. Will the two of them get back together? }} {{Book list | book_number = 62 | title = ''Who's Who?'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = January 1, 1990 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Deciding that the boys she's been dating are all the same, Jessica signs up with a dating agency and creates two drastically different identities. This attracts two different guys, but doesn't keep her from making dates with both of them for the same night.... }} {{Book list | book_number = 63 | title = ''The New Elizabeth'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = February 1, 1990 | line_color = novel | short_summary = To shake off her stodgy image, Elizabeth decides to try surfing. }} {{Book list | book_number = 64 | title = ''The Ghost of Tricia Martin'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = February 8, 2000 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Steven meets a girl who is eerily like his late girlfriend Tricia, to the dismay of his current girlfriend Cara. }} {{Book list | book_number = 65 | title = ''Trouble at Home'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 1, 1990 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Alice and Ned Wakefield split up, and when Jessica thinks it's Liz's fault, her distraught twin mulls moving away from home: if she's the cause of their split, they'll reunite when she's gone. Enid suspects foul play from attention-hog Jessica. }} {{Book list | book_number = 66 | title = ''Who's to Blame?'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = June 1, 1990 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica cruelly blames Liz for their parents' trial separation, and Liz stays at Enid's. Steven and Cara discover Jessica's cruel plot to keep their parents apart so they'll divorce and she can play matchmaker by setting them up with other people. Having seen her for the cruel person she is, Cara assists Steven in helping him find Liz. With evidence against Jessica: Steven, Cara, and Enid confronts her. They give her an ultimatum: apologize to Liz or risk exposure that will result in a lengthy [[punishment|grounding]] and public embarrassment. Jessica refuses and calls their bluff. }} {{Book list | book_number = 67 | title = ''The Parent Plot'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = July 1, 1990 | line_color = novel | short_summary = While Liz, Steven, and Cara scheme to reunite the Wakefield parents, Jessica is still determined to see her plan through by keeping them apart. She encourages Mr. Wakefield to run for mayor and Alice to date Mr. Collins. However, her plans run afoul when Alice learns about Jessica's plans from Steven and confronts her for it. Alice and Ned reconcile, while Jessica is punished with public humiliation and a lengthy grounding for her actions. }} {{Book list | book_number = 68 | title = ''The Love Bet'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = August 1, 1990 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Liz and Todd try to get Dana Larson and Aaron Dallas together, even when both of them "don't believe in love". }} {{Book list | book_number = 69 | title = ''Friend Against Friend'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = 1990 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Best friends Andy and Neil are really close. Then racist bully Charlie Cashman targets Andy because he's black. Attempting to cope with this, Andy starts pushing Neil away. Then one night Neil betrays Andy in a shocking way. }} {{Book list | book_number = 70 | title = ''Ms. Quarterback'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = 1990 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Claire Middleton becomes the star quarterback of the football team to the guys' dismay - which turns to admiration. }} {{Book list | book_number = 71 | title = ''Starring Jessica!'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = 1990 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica and Lila become rivals again when vying to appear on Eric Parker's TV talk show. Lila's sometime rival Bruce aids her, having his own score to settle with Jessica. Can Elizabeth's own trickery hold back Lila and Bruce? }} {{Book list | book_number = 72 | title = ''Rock Star's Girl'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = 1991 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Andrea Slade hides the fact that her father, Jamie Peters, is a rock star so people will like her for who she is ... of course, Lila and Jessica will stop at nothing to find out her connection to Jamie. }} {{Book list | book_number = 73 | title = ''Regina's Legacy'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = 1991 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Mrs. Morrow gives Liz Regina's old camera as a keepsake. Liz takes an incriminating photo and finds her life on the line. }} {{Book list | book_number = 74 | title = ''The Perfect Girl'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = 1991 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Robin Wilson is so scared that her boyfriend George Warren will leave her for Vicky that she starves herself, thinking he won't leave her if she's slimmer. When Elizabeth and her aunt catches on, they convince Robin to get help at once. }} {{Book list | book_number = 75 | title = ''Amy's True Love'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 1, 1991 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Amy goes after top tennis player Tom McKay. He eventually comes out as gay, but she finds her true love in his friend, Barry Rork. }} {{Book list | book_number = 76 | title = ''Miss Teen Sweet Valley'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = May 1, 1991 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Feminist Liz and traditionalist Jess clash over Jess becoming Miss Teen Sweet Valley. }} {{Book list | book_number =77 | title = ''Cheating to Win'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = June 1, 1991 | line_color = novel | short_summary = When Tony Esteban starts taking steroids, his girlfriend Annie Whitman tries to get him off them. }} {{Book list | book_number = 78 | title = ''The Dating Game'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = August 1, 1991 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica starts dropping guys—then she sends a break-up text to Todd by mistake. }} {{Book list | book_number = 79 | title = ''The Long-Lost Brother'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = May 8, 2001 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth's friend Sara Eastbourne's brother comes home after being in Connecticut. }} {{Book list | book_number = 80 | title = ''The Girl They Both Loved'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = June 12, 2001 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Artie Western and Michael Harris relentlessly compete over fellow motorbike enthusiast April Dawson. }} {{Book list | book_number = 81 | title = ''Rosa's Lie'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = July 10, 2001 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Rose Jameson is hiding her Mexican heritage (and real name, Rosa) from everyone at school because she just moved to Sweet Valley; she wants a fresh start and thinks she can be anyone she wants to be. }} {{Book list | book_number = 82 | title = ''Kidnapped by the Cult!'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = January 1, 1992 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Grounded for her poor math grades, Jessica feels that nobody cares about her plight. She gets taken in by a group of people called The Good Friends, but by the time she realizes what they really are, it might be too late.... }} {{Book list | book_number = 83 | title = ''Steven's Bride'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 11, 2001 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Cara Walker is moving to London, and a devastated Steven proposes so they can stay together. Elizabeth and Cara have become close friends—will they be sisters now? }} {{Book list | book_number = 84 | title = ''The Stolen Diary'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = March 1, 1992 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth dates a new guy, Kris, but when she rejects him he gets his hands on her journal and spreads a lot of rumors about her. Can an infuriated twin restore Liz's good reputation? }} {{Book list | book_number = 85 | title = ''Soap Star'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 1, 1992 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica and a very reluctant Elizabeth get parts on a soap whose star cruelly attempts to break Jessica's heart, but she uses her character's role to break up with him and exact revenge at the same time. }} {{Book list | book_number = 86 | title = ''Jessica Against Bruce'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = June 1, 1992 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Deciding things are getting too dull around Sweet Valley, Bruce stars the secret, men-only "Club X." Infuriated by this chauvinistic declaration, Jessica decides to prove that girls are as tough as boys, if not tougher than! What follows is a series of dares and pranks throughout the school and town, a display that disrupts a visiting delegation of foreign teachers, for which Liz is a student guide. }} {{Book list | book_number = 87 | title = ''My Best Friend's Boyfriend'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = August 1, 1992 | line_color = novel | short_summary = When a guy phoning the teen hotline for which she is volunteering asks to meet her in person, Ginny Belasca is worried that her looks will disappoint him so asks her prettier friend Denise to met him. She does - and develops feelings for him too. Meanwhile, Jess enlists Liz's help in investigating a sexual-harassment claim. }} {{Book list | book_number = 88 | title = ''Love Letters for Sale'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 1, 1992 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica and Elizabeth start a letter-writing business and Jessica reads a letter from Shelley Novak, who has fallen for Todd Wilkis and wants them to write him a letter to ask him out. Not realizing what she's doing, Elizabeth writes the letter—and it works! Will Todd and Elizabeth stay together, or will the two basketball stars fall in love? }} {{Book list | book_number = 89 | title = ''Elizabeth Betrayed'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = October 1, 1992 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Someone plagiarizes Elizabeth's writings, almost ruining her job at ''The Oracle'' and her friendship with Olivia. When Jessica discovered the plagiarizer is none other than the jealous John Pfeifer(whom Liz refused a date with), she uses her scheming ways to humiliate him by exposing him to everyone at the school. Her actions restore Liz's reputation and John's own reputation is ruined. }} {{Book list | book_number = 90 | title = ''Don't Go Home With John'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = December 1, 1992 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Despite Jessica warning Lila to stay away from John Pfeifer after his attempt to ruin Liz's reputation, she ignores the warning and pays for it. She is almost date-raped by him and he begins to torment her. When another girl he almost raped steps forward and exposes John, everyone shuns him. John is then arrested and put in a mental asylum. }} {{Book list | book_number = 91 | title = ''In Love With a Prince'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = January 1, 1993 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Dana, lead singer of the band The Droids, falls in love with Prince Arthur, the twins' friend. }} {{Book list | book_number = 92 | title = ''She's Not What She Seems'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = February 1, 1993 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica befriends sophomore Paula Perrine, who briefly overtakes her with her own brand of stealthy conniving. Only Liz could stop Paula with her own brand of honesty and scheming. }} {{Book list | book_number = 93 | title = ''Stepsisters'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = March 1, 1993 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Annie Whitman's mom is getting remarried and Annie is thrilled to be getting a new stepsister as well. When she discovers that Cheryl is black, she invites all the black and Asian kids from school although she doesn't know half of them, in a misguided but well-meaning attempt to prove her open-mindedness. }} {{Book list | book_number = 94 | title = ''Are We In Love?'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 1, 1993 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Cheryl and Steven are really good friends, but in a series of misunderstandings they end up as a couple, which some people have a problem with as they're an interracial couple. }} {{Book list | book_number = 95 | title = ''The Morning After'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = June 1, 1993 | line_color = novel | short_summary = The aftermath of the tragic prom, including the death of Jessica's boyfriend Sam Woodruff. }} {{Book list | book_number = 96 | title = ''The Arrest'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = July 1, 1993 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth is arrested for manslaughter in the drunk-driving accident that killed Sam. Jessica seeks revenge by stealing Todd from Elizabeth. However, guilt starts to set in when Jessica starts to be haunted by nightmares in what she did to spike Elizabeth's drink. }} {{Book list | book_number = 97 | title = ''The Verdict'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = August 1, 1993 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth is acquitted of manslaughter. She figures out that Jessica spiked her punch with alcohol and did nothing to stop her from leaving the prom, and the twins are torn apart ... And they're not the only ones. }} {{Book list | book_number = 98 | title = ''The Wedding'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 1, 1993 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Lila's divorced parents remarry. Liz and Todd fight about where they stand, as do Jess and Todd. }} {{Book list | book_number = 99 | title = ''Beware the Baby-Sitter'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = October 1, 1993 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Margo is ever closer to Sweet Valley, but must contend Josh who is determined to stop her. }} {{Book list | book_number = 100 | title = ''The Evil Twin'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = November 1, 1993 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Margo arrives in Sweet Valley and begins her plan to become Elizabeth. It culminates at Lila's New Year's Eve bash, when Margo plans to murder Elizabeth and assume her identity. Jessica intervenes just in time, and Margo dies instead of Liz when Josh pushes her to her death. The traumatic situation bonds Liz and Jess all over agan as Liz also discovers how she got drunk the night of Jungle Prom. }} {{Book list | book_number = 101 | title = ''The Boyfriend War'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = December 1, 1993 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Lila tricks Jessica into being a counselor in Kiddie Club Paradise and Mick, the sexy windbreaker at the camp, has to choose between them. }} {{Book list | book_number = 102 | title = ''Almost Married'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = January 1, 1994 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth and Bruce learn that Alice Wakefield and Hank Patman, who had once been engaged, are having an affair, and forge a truce to try to end the situation. When Ned finds out about it, he and Alice have a serious fight as do Hank and Marie(who also found out about the affair). Ned and Alice suffer marital problems again and live separately. Only this time, Jessica is more willing to help Ned and Alice reconcile. Todd asks Liz to live with him in the Wakefield home. }} {{Book list | book_number = 103 | title = ''Operation Love Match'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = February 1, 1994 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Liz and Jessica's plot to reunite Hank and Marie Patman takes an unexpected turn. Jessica is arrested by the police when they discover her digging though the mailbox, looking the envelope containing her own letter to her boyfriend that she accidentally send off to Hank and not the letter that Liz wrote for Bruce's mother, Marie. After clarifying things with the police, Ned grounds Jessica again and tells her off that she must work at the post office part time if she wants to avoid jail time. He also grounds Elizabeth after learning about her and Todd living together. }} {{Book list | book_number = 104 | title = ''Love and Death in London'' | author = Kate William | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = March 1, 1994 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Liz and Jessica begin their scariest adventures as interns in London. }} {{Book list | book_number = 105 | title = ''A Date With a Werewolf'' | author = Kate William | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 1, 1994 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Liz falls for a dark, handsome English stranger named Luke, who has a dark secret. }} {{Book list | book_number = 106 | title = ''Beware the Wolfman'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = May 1, 1994 | line_color = novel | short_summary = The London story is wrapped up as Liz's friend Luke is discovered to be the werewolf and she is devastated by his death. }} {{Book list | book_number = 107 | title = ''Jessica's Secret Love'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = June 1, 1994 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica falls in love with an older man: Jeremy, the fiance' of her houseguest Sue. }} {{Book list | book_number = 108 | title = ''Left At the Altar'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = July 1, 1994 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Sue and Jeremy's beachfront weddingis demolished by Hurricane Jessica; Elizabeth and Todd reveal what they did when they were apart. }} {{Book list | book_number = 109 | title = ''Double Crossed'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 1, 1994 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jeremy cheats on his new fiancee Jessica with his OLD fiancee Sue! }} {{Book list | book_number = 110 | title = ''Death Threat'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = October 1, 1994 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Sue's life is on the line and the twins suspect who might be behind the scheme. }} {{Book list | book_number = 111 | title = '' A Deadly Christmas'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = November 1, 1994 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jeremy's scheme to steal Sue's fortune is exposed and he is arrested. }} {{Book list | book_number = 112 | title = ''Jessica Quits the Squad'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = December 1, 1994 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica finds herself in a rivalry with Heather Mallone, who becomes the new co-captain. Jessica also becomes romantically involved with Ken Matthews much to Heather's jealousy. And could Elizabeth have a secret desire for him too? }} {{Book list | book_number = 113 | title = ''The Pom-Pom Wars'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = January 1, 1995 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica forms her own cheerleading squad, which includes Elizabeth. Elizabeth betrays Jessica and Todd to discover the truth about her feelings for Ken. Todd discovers Elizabeth and Ken's secret romance. }} {{Book list | book_number = 114 | title = ''"V" For Victory'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = February 1, 1995 | line_color = novel | short_summary = The two squads vie for victory. Heather Mallone's past isn't perfect and her cool demeamor crumbles. When Todd, Ken, and Winston come to cheer on the Sweet Valley High girls' squad, they become cheerleaders themselves! }} {{Book list | book_number = 115 | title = ''The Treasure of Death Valley'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 1, 1995 | line_color = novel | short_summary = A handful of students are selected to go on a hike through Death Valley: Liz, Jess, Todd, Ken, Bruce, and Heather. While hiking, they stumble upon a treasure map that promises to lead them to great fortune, but following the map means leaving the planned trail, which could be dangerous. Meanwhile, a dangerous group stalks them through the desert... }} {{Book list | book_number = 116 | title = ''Nightmare In Death Valley'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = May 1, 1995 | line_color = novel | short_summary = The group find the treasure but are soon attacked by the convicts. How will they escape? Will they get to keep the gold or be forced to leave it behind? }} {{Book list | book_number = 117 | title = ''Jessica the Genius'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = August 1, 1995 | line_color = novel | short_summary =Jessica is accused of cheating on the SATs, and Elizabeth sets out to prove her twin's innocence. }} {{Book list | book_number = 118 | title = ''College Weekend'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 1st 1995 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica and Elizabeth visit Steven at Sweet Valley University }} {{Book list | book_number = 119 | title = ''Jessica's Older Guy'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = October 1, 1995 | line_color = novel | short_summary = When Jessica and Elizabeth decide to stay at SVU, their friends plot to bring them home. }} {{Book list | book_number = 120 | title = ''In Love With the Enemy'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = December 1, 1995 | line_color = novel | short_summary = The rivalry between SVH and Palisades High becomes a bitter feud as Jessica falls for Palisades student Christian Gorman, betrays her boyfriend Ken Matthews in the process. A gang war starts and nobody can stop it. On the lighter side, Jessica and Lila bet on Jessica's chances of winning a surfing contest. }} {{Book list | book_number = 121 | title = ''The High School War'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date =January 1, 1996 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica and Christian aim to make their relationship work, in spite of the anger and animosity at both schools. }} {{Book list | book_number = 122 | title = ''A Kiss Before Dying'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = February 1, 1996 | line_color = novel | short_summary = The feud between Palisades and SVH reaches a deadly conclusion when Christian Gorman is accidentally killed. The surfing contest also happens. }} {{Book list | book_number = 123 | title = ''Elizabeth's Rival'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 1, 1996 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth is reunited with middle-school bestie Maria Slater at a special summer camp for the arts, but they must endure Maria's current best friend's scheming antics. Meanwhile, Jessica meets someone who might be able to help her recover from Christian's tragic death. }} {{Book list | book_number = 124 | title = ''Meet Me at Midnight'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = June 1996 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth falls for a camp counselor; Jessica frets over her fiery relationship with Paul. }} {{Book list | book_number = 125 | title = ''Camp Killer'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date =June 1, 1996 | line_color = novel | short_summary = A scary camp legend proves true when a crazy mountain man near the camp kidnaps and tries to kill a camper and one of the twins. }} {{Book list | book_number = 126 | title = ''Tall, Dark and Deadly'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = August 1, 1996 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Newcomer Jonathan Cain is tall, dark, handsome, and mysterious ... and sudden deaths occur at his entrance. SVH students follow him like adoring fans; Jessica Wakefield feels a supernatural pull to him. The only student who adamantly distrusts and dislikes Jonathan is Elizabeth, who finds him disturbing. Jessica seems unable to entice Jonathan, despite how sure she is of their destiny. Elizabeth's past summer fling threatens her future with Todd. Maria Slater returns to Sweet Valley and joins Elizabeth at Sweet Valley High, and Enid is jealous. }} {{Book list | book_number = 127 | title = ''Dance of Death'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = September 1, 1996 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Jessica and Jonathan appear to be moving forward, or at least Jessica thinks so, as her classmates continue to be obsessed with Jonathan. Amy's cousin Katrina's visit to Sweet Valley ends horrifically. Enid brags about her exploits with Jonathan, much to Jessica's fury and Elizabeth's concern. The Sweet Valley High guys plan a wild party at Jonathan's house. Joey and Elizabeth begin moving forward, as Todd and Elizabeth disintegrate. The path of murders continues. }} {{Book list | book_number = 128 | title = ''Kiss of a Killer'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = October 1, 1996 | line_color = novel | short_summary = After Katrina's death at Jonathan Cain's house, Elizabeth investigates his past, becoming ever more shocked and terrified by her finds. Jonathan takes Jessica to his favorite hangout - which happens to be where the murderer took his victims. Jessica plans to depart with Jonathan as she falls into his trance. Jonathan puts Enid in a coma, but shows remorse and spares her life. The Sweet Valley High fans become less adoring and more suspicious and finally discover the truth. Joey and Elizabeth finds themselves incompatible. Todd and Elizabeth become romantically involved again. Elizabeth spares Jonathan and Jonathan departs, which lifts the curse he'd had over Sweet Valley. }} {{Book list | book_number = 129 | title = ''Cover Girls'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date =February 10, 1997 | line_color = novel | short_summary = The twins get internships at a fashion magazine. Elizabeth aims to learn about journalism while Jessica aims to become a supermodel. When Todd's the one who gets discovered and becomes a model, Jessica sees green and red.... which Elizabeth sees when she finds him in the arms of another woman. }} {{Book list | book_number = 130 | title = ''Model Flirt'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = March 10, 1997 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth's new mentor at the fashion magazine steals her idea for a column and attempts to murder her to keep her secret. Jessica gets closer to achieving her goal. }} {{Book list | book_number = 131 | title = ''Fashion Victim'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 7, 1997 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth and Jessica team up to get their revenge on those who have wronged them. }} {{Book list | book_number = 132 | title = ''Once Upon a Time'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = May 12, 1997 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth and Jessica travel to France to be au pairs for a royal family. Elizabeth falls for Prince Laurent and Jessica falls for jewel thief Jacques. }} {{Book list | book_number = 133 | title = ''To Catch a Thief'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = July 7, 1997 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth and Jessica are on the run after being falsely accused of stealing Antonia's diamond necklace and the Countess' emerald pendant. Meanwhile, Jacques feels guilty for his mistake and must atone for them. }} {{Book list | book_number =134 | title = ''Happily Ever After'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = August 11, 1997 | line_color = novel | short_summary = The twins' names are cleared. Prince Laurent refuses to marry Antonia and proposes to Elizabeth. She refuses and returns to Sweet Valley where she reconciles with Todd. Jacques admits to the theft and is arrested. Prince Laurent helps him and his father escape. }} {{Book list | book_number = 135 | title = ''Lila's New Flame'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = October 6, 1997 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Lila ends her relationship with Bo and her mansion catches fire. She awakens in the hospital with the twins by her side. No one is able to locate her parents, as they are taking a second honeymoon and are unreachable on their remote island. The investigation report finds the fire at Fowler Crest to be an act of arson due to the traces of gasoline all over the estate. The DA suspects Lila as the arsonist as a cry for attention. Steven Wakefield and longtime girlfriend Bille end their relationship and Steven begins his internship at the DA's office. As the DA's suspicion in Lila grows, so do Steven's romantic feelings for Lila. Devon Whitelaw has just lost both his parents and tries to find other relatives he can trust. }} {{Book list | book_number = 136 | title = ''Too Hot To Handle'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = November 10, 1997 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Devon Whitelaw heads to Las Vegas to find a long-lost uncle. Lila and Steven continue their romance while Steven looks for clues about who destroyed Fowler Crest. }} {{Book list | book_number = 137 | title = ''Fight Fire With Fire'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = December 1, 1997 | line_color = novel | short_summary = John's attempt to destroy Lila ends up destroying him. Jessica and Elizabeth must pay for their assumptions when Lila and Steven confront them. Devon finds an old nanny who reveals the truth of his parents' sordid past and neglect. }} {{Book list | book_number = 138 | title = ''What Jessica Wants...'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = February 9, 1998 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Devon Whitelaw is the new student at Sweet Valley High: Jessica wants him but he falls for Elizabeth, but Jessica wants him. }} {{Book list | book_number = 139 | title = ''Elizabeth is Mine'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = March 9, 1998 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth Wakefield never planned on straying from her longtime boyfriend, Todd Wilkins. But she'd never met anyone like Devon Whitelaw. He's devastatingly sexy, brilliant, and impossible for her to resist. When he rejects Jessica, she attempts to seduce Todd for revenge. Elizabeth tries to break up with Todd gently, but the more she pushes him away, the tighter he clings. Can Elizabeth make Todd understand that she no longer loves him without breaking his heart? }} {{Book list | book_number = 140 | title = ''Please Forgive Me'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = April 6, 1998 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth Wakefield's heart is being ripped to shreds. The rivalry between her longtime boyfriend Todd Wilkins and the mysterious Devon Whitelaw has erupted into violence. Forget choosing between them - a disgusted Elizabeth ditches them both. Unless they can both grow up, she'll never speak to either one of them again! Horrified and feeling guilty that he flew off the handle, Todd understands why Elizabeth will have nothing to do with him. But he's not about to give up without a fight. When a dance that Elizabeth is organizing doesn't go as planned, Todd seizes the opportunity to prove how far he'll go to win her forgiveness. But will his desperate effort push him over the edge? }} {{Book list | book_number = 141 | title = ''A Picture-Perfect Prom?'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = May 11, 1998 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth needs to make a decision fast. She told both of her ex-boyfriends, devoted Todd and sexy Devon, that she needed time to stand on her own. But now she's totally alone, without a prom date! Will she be able to figure our who her dream guy is...before he asks someone else? Meanwhile Jessica attempts to ask Devon out herself, but he refuses having seen her for the selfish, conniving and manipulative person she is. }} {{Book list | book_number =142 | title = ''The Big Night'' | author = Francine Pascal | publisher = [[Random House]] | publish_date = June 8, 1998 | line_color = novel | short_summary = Elizabeth is walking on air. She can't wait to attend the prom on the arm of her sexy date, Devon Whitelaw.
